title: December 7
description:
Lucie has a new job. Okay, a contract job, but she will be there for six whole months (six!). She's used to 6 week contracts, so this is feeling like a VERY long engagement.

She's working on the website of Spore, an award-winning video game. It's conveniently located 5 minutes from Ecole Bilingue. The product is great, the people are cool, the schedule is flexible. Sweet!

The kids love the game. When they play it, they are convinced they're helping mom with her job. Lucie is happy to have them relate to her work, for once.

children.title: Charlotte
children.description: Connor turned 6 and his twin sisters are 6 months old. Milo loves playing with those babies so much he asked their parents whether we could take one home.  They said no.  Milo pointed out "but you have two of them, and we don't have any."  They still said no.  Darn.

children.title: Explorers
children.description: Connor's dad Patrick distributes booty during the Birthday Treasure Hunt, which took us around the neighborhood.

children.title: Museum
children.description:
Felix never gets bored, but his playing style is messy. He's always spreading stuff all over the house, pretending he is running a store, or a space station, or (pictured) a museum.

Now that the kids are older we're trying to reign in the mess downstairs. It's hard to find the right balance: we like it when they play down where we are, but do they really have to dump 1000-piece Lego sets in the middle of living room?

children.title: Travel Bug
children.description: This travel bug travelled all the way from Quebec to Berkeley. How did it do it? How did we get it? What's a travel bug anyway? Read on.

children.title: Geocaching
children.description:
We spent Sunday geocaching, same as last weekend. We're hooked!

One of the best thing about our new hobby is wandering through little-travelled alleys, cute stairways and secluded parks. The appeal of the chase is enough to keep the kids walking for hours.

children.title: Where?
children.description: Can you spot the cache in this picture?

children.title: There!
children.description:
There it is!

This was a good one. It contained a travel bug: a little car with an ID tag on it. According to the travel bug's log (which we accessed via a website), it started in Quebec, then went to Hawaii and New Mexico, before wandering around the Bay Area.

children.title: Slide
children.description: Of the 4 of us, Milo's interest in geocaching is the weakest. We gave him a chance to play at Cordonices Park while we plotted our next adventure: hiding a geocache of our own.

children.title: Camouflage
children.description: Since last weekend Dean acquired a small mound of geocaching paraphernalia (of course), including a roll of camouflage duct tape.

children.title: Duct Tape
children.description: This is actually the same box that we hid last weekend. We found out another cache already existed less than .3 miles from our spot. That's against the rules, so we had to  find it a new home.

children.title: Ready
children.description:
Try finding THAT in the bushes!

Unfortunately, it turned out this park ALSO has a previous cache, so we'll have to retrieve ours, once again. We'll do our homework more carefully next time. Berkeley is littered with caches!

children.title: Candle Dinner
children.description:
It's cold. We've been firing up the wood stove. To make the most of it, we moved the table and had a candle-lit, fire-lit dinner.

Dean told scary stories about the geo-goblins, nasty little creatures who play dirty tricks to people who steal from geocaches.
